thought bene sine felle without gall butter would melt mouth may perceyue vntrue hath ben reported woulde farther thinke shoulde compare beeing c take othe tooke admitted fellowe c item buic collegio redinesse people know euery man may see ready shake calling vpon euery light occasion neither preach place gospell hath bin well planted loyter lesse nede easily may make sturres moue contention number likelyhoodes charged minister place dissolutdnesse losenesse lyfe corruption manner allcadge proue able teache instructe agaynst dumbe ministerie abroade followeth vttereth onely great line maye vntruth falsification author sheweth minde desirous slaunder sorie seemeth greuously discredite lyker anabaptistes wyll set downe wordes written leafe may appeare howe faythfully haue dealte libere enim dicunt concionatores qui sripendium accipiunt non esse veros deiministros neque posse docere ueritatem sed esse uentris ministros qui line iose accipiant ingentia stipendia ex illis rebus quae simulachris immolatae fuerunt ex diuitijs splendide luxuriose uiuant cum tamen christus dixit gratis accepistis gratis date prohibuit duas tunica peram pecuniam habere preterea paulum aiunt manibus suis laborasse mandasse reliquis ut idem faciant itaque concludunt nulla debere stipendia habere sui officii sed laborare gratis ministrare quia hoc non faciunt non posse ipsos ueritatem docere saywhat thing assirmed seconde article freely speaking anabaptistes preacher take stipendes true minister god teach truthe minister bellie liue idlely take gret stipendes thing offered image rich liue gorgeously riotousely notwithstanding christ sayde ye haue receyued freely giue freely forbad haue two coates scrippe money besydes say paule laboured owne handes gaue commaundement rest minister shoulde doe therefore conclude haue stipende office labour minister nought bicause cannot teach truthe nowe let men iudge whether one thing say ought haue stipendes labour saye anabaptistes sayde lawfull haue stipende say could teach truely bicause great liuings bicause liuings although neuer read heard meane say great stipendes liuings could preach truely may diuers haue sayd meete minister content competent stipendes ouerplus might go supplie want minister liuings maintenaunce poore vniuersitie excesse cause diuers disorder person haue could preach truely preached great liuings parte neuer hearde thinke would exempted reprehension wherein faulte therefore knowe meane word dyd thing themselues thei taught others professe perfectio liues oftentimes behind great dealein taught dueties doe therefore thinke necessarie reprehended shewed faultes whereas say anabaptistes accused minister giuing much magistrate haue shewed giue little shewe v amende fault assure greeueth euen beginning wearie turning vp note mo line est line manerly speaches dung refuting baine friuolous sclanders shewe face truthe therfore briefe rest io whitgifte speake doctrine anabaptist certaine note wherby may knowne quality manner talke preaching wordes bullingers mine argumentes framed neither mine disciple magnifie bicause vsuall talke publike priuate isthey seke reformatio diffamation minister minister church calling preaching life c doe reforme doe absence people deface discredite promote gospell preache diligently syncerely doe bring hatred people whereby might rather preuaile enterprise reforme manner maye compare wyth kynde honestie dutie erpresse malice wrathe whiche zuinglius anabap elench contra anabap speaketh melancholie wrathe true zeale whiche glorie maye truly verified thereof let thys booke iudge nowe say poynte agree anabaptistes doe therefore straighteway conclude anabaptistes thys conclude suche inuemues bee esteemed pure deede brother thorough suche slaunde line o speaches bee discredited bycause herein speake practise nothyng agaynste true minister woorde god whyche anabaptistes haue doone selfe forme manner quality woorthie bee obserued anabaptistes suche proceede lyke manner may appeare onely obseruation buliinger learned godlie menne also haue written agaynste giuen note quality zuinglius booke named sayth speake euyll bothe ibidem speake euill magistrate line idem line le ciuill magistrate minister churche anye tyme eyther accordyng theyr office reproue streyghtwaye saye therefore bee enimyes vnto bycause tell theyr faultes ecclesiast sayeth thus line slaunder reuyle backebyte minister woorde churche oughte suspected hated godlye menne euen theyr slaunderous curssed speakyng theyr ende purpose thys meanes wynne credite vnto selues discredite suche sette selues agaynste detecte theyr erroures lyke saying hathe hys booke de baptismo effecte also speaketh gastius booke de exordio erroribus catabap gastiu line among sentence hath thys theyr talke vttereth nothyng else reprehension minister worde libertie externall thing iudge praye whether hath ben qualitie woorthie bee obserued anabaptistes doe speake agaynste suche modestly accordyng rule apostle tunoth doo reproue agaynste haue nothing else theyr mouthes inuectiues agaynste minister woorde obseruyng neyther place tyme anye circumstance whome still say poynt fitly compared anabaptist nowe whether bee logike gyue taste thys placelette learned reader iudge whome also committe tryall thys spyrite whyche bursteth suche vnseemely manner vpon consyderation owne deuysed argumentes feede contempte disdayne deede make argumentes make none frame pleaseth meruayle though make long booke cause reader beleeue logicke simple woulde haue deale mee vprightly honestly set downe vnskilfulnesse spare trust woulde doo vttermost euery poynt could seeing doe occasion offered vnto mee imagined youre selfe well let quarelles goe meete among boyes among men gratia dei sum quod sum neyther haue thing whiche haue receyued commeth good thing bothe election minister excommunication thynke declare god willing proper place woordes alledged haue saide master bullingers truly spoken good purpose shall appeare meane referre magistrate electing minister leaues booke aduersus anabap excommunication leafe booke denye saye lawfull ordinarye callyng mynisters englande whych strange hearyng mee wherevnto tendeth whych wrytten booke touching electing calling minister orf line st admonition contrarie c written fyrst admonition folio say playne termes wee haue neyther ryghte ministerie god righte gouernement hys churche folio c folio saye thys prescripte forme seruice vsed churche englande mayntayneth vnlawfull ministerie whyche bytterly spoken agaynst booke orderyng minister deacon whyche call pontificall saye may lawfully called whyche ordinarilye woulde haue speake playnely calling ministerie england lawful ordinarie lawfull agaynste woorde god neyther lawe scripture contrarie woulde make v beleeue truly thynke well aduysed else haue suttle meaning adde immediately place englande minister called theyr parish c suppose meane parish englande lawfull callyng minister bee withstanding truly sayde denie maner callyng minister churche englande lawfull maner callyng ascribed churche vsed conuenticles secrete congregation allowed publike common authoritie distinction lawfull ordinarie simply good whatsoeuer lawfulllauful ordinarie church established church established ordinarie think euen comon reason dothe teache true wherfore certaynly ministerie bee lawfull ordinarie parishe englande doe electe call minister otherwyse order lawes thys churche dothe permitte see howe parishe excuse selfe schisme thinke verilye churche englande c pag sect vlt salomon sayth beginnyng line ordes vnwise man folyshnesse b line theecclef ver latter ende mere madnesse euen oute whilest suffer selfe caryed headlong affection hurle knowe whome whatsoeuer commeth firste hande speake thing eye eares men fee heare otherwyse yo line anabaptistes donatistes friende mighte thinke sayde bycause suche alway line seekyng darke solitarie place myghte happely haue fauourers whych knowne ioyne wyth papistes whych commonly knowne men whose doctrine imp line gne yet defacing depr line uing church england fully ioyne wyth line oe well whose markes badge lesse awaye wyth whose companie flie whose punishment haue called parte haue done therefore condemned line ruell oftentymes carie awaye name myldnesse moderation whych forsothe knowe haue professed commandement scripture put heretickes death saye ioyne thus wyth papistes doe line nely credite vntrue furmises wherein truste wyth indifferent reader neuer make thing suspected gyue occasion take vp common prouerbe agaynst wyll truste farther see haue thus yoked papistes go aboute shewe wherein drawe wyth wherein fyrst aske affyrme doe thyng enimyes churche doe forthwith line oyned conspired church say neither christe paule ioyned either gentil line phariseis false apostle church say paule ioyned wyth pharise line sact v resurrection false apostle taking wage corinthian our2 cor ii v sauiour christ spake agaynst jewes onely people god gentils dyd enimyes saye therefore eyther sainte paule line cor ioyned wyth phariseys false apostle agaynst churche sauiour christ ioyned agaynst jewes wyth gentils let v see slaunders particularly io whitgifte salomon sayth mouthe foolyshe roote pridepro c euen falleth oute whylest suche proude wordes seeke dryue doe condemne selfe follye pylate herodemen contrarie iudgements ioyne togither truthe enimitie betwi line te selues yet wyned together againste christ phariseis saduces contrarie opinion yet enimyes doctrine christ turke pope contrarie religion yet doe conspire agaynst gospell papistes anabaptistes agree eyther opinion societie yet doe seeke deface church christe euen thoughe impugne doctrine papist neuer line ly cast away markes badge neuer farre though cannot abyde theyr companie yet doe wyth assertion thoughe argumentes assaulte churche englande bende force dyd seditious iewes within ierusalem ioyne wyth romains beyng enimyes inprocuring destruction citie ignoraunt woulde seeme sure vnderstande meaning howe haue called punishement papistes haue therefore counted cruell made moderate certaynely knowe heare onely selfe saye haue done minde bragge time leaue haue professed concernyng putting deathe herotickes doe professe still ready thereof gyue accompte tymes shal required although neyther man else haue heard teach doctrine professe thys one glance waye occasion gyuen speake matter wyll plainely vtter conscience grace god meane tyme cause shoulde better thoughte among papistes bothe theyr practise theyr doctrine eleane contrarie question answere doe church enimyes doe doe conspire wyth churche therefore example line vsed purpose saynt paule ioyned wyth phariseys wyth false propheteo thyngs allowed churche commoditie church therefore respecte agaynst churche answere make example christe iustly reprouing iewes woulde haue vsed apte example purpose shoulde haue broughte suche beyng contrarie iudgementes haue notwythsta line dyng soughte ouerthrowe one selfe thing althoughe diuers meanes shoulde haue concluded agaynst selfe must necessitie dee would seeme say much haue saide nothing io whitgifte exhortation c pag sect vlt first papistes affirme true churche haue much outward face true church doe men almost flat playne termes c pag sect doe denie visible church god england therefore saying doe almost plaine flat termes say haue muche outwarde face shewe true church argueth haue almost loue whieh vpon one word vttered contrarie tenour booke course whole life surmise truely conclude word scarce shall appeare come place io whitgifte doe playne flat termes write muche doe reporte article manyfest proofe thereof line referre reader page seconde admonition first admonition whole discourse almost equiualent searse whosoeuer shall well consider tenour theyr bookes course lyfe may easily vnderstande myghte haue lefte oute almost theyr scarse lykewise io whitgifte exhortation c pag sect secondly papistes say haue ministerie byshops pastours bicause rightly canonically called function selfe men affirme c pag sect haue answered seconde article anabaptisme charge v io whitgifte haue answered also io whitgifte exhortation c pag sect thirdly papistes say sacrament rightly ministred say likewise c page sect also answered thirde io whitgifte haue closely confessed true reader may vnderstande truely verifyed let peruse written seconde admonition fol saye sacrament wickedly2 admon fol ministred first admonition communicate v lordes supper men would haue lawes punishment compelled thervnto c pag sect vlt answere doeg saide dauid came abimilech sayde nothing truth witnessed christ sayde destroy temple three dayes build vp againe saide nothing sauiour christ sayde yet doeg slaunderer false witness bycause one spake minde hurte vnderstoode another temple sauiour christ ment although parte rehearse wordes yet taking contrary meaning might easily appeare circumstance see howe bee free faultes vnlesse done ignorantly wishe true owne sake wyll desire thee gentle reader marke conscience man sayth ioyned confederate papistes agaynst church papistes mislyke booke common prayer nothing else bycause swarueth masse booke poyntes lyke vnto men mislyke nothing else hath much lykelyhoode vnto iudge whether ioyned papistes woulde haue communion fellowship wyth neyther ceremony doctrine gouernment forsaking doctrine reteyne part theyr ceremony almost whole gouernment separate themselues three walles one woulde parted broade sea woulde beuided narrowe water maye make bridge come agayne displace truth gospell haue done tymes past woulde onely vnhorse pope also take awaye styrrops whereby shoulde neuer get sadle agayne beyng content wyth vnhorsed leaue ceremony gouernment especially styrrops whereby maye leape vp agayne occasion serueth content onely haue cut armes body antichristianitie would haue stumpe roote vp io whitgifte better haue bad excuse none word meaning playne shal appeare come thinke deede meaning would haue copelled come church communicate lordes supper v nowe ministred well knowne howe themselues refuse howe haue defaced church manner forme administring sacrament woulde doe might haue owne deuised reformation haue lawe owne handes tell lyke woulde sharpe seuere inough compelling men come speake opinion touching compelling men come churche vnto whiche come themselues whiche followeth replie haue sufficiently answered beforepag haue declared howe straunge thing men cleane contrarie iudgementes opinion ioyne togither oppugning one selfe truthe papistes pretende one cause misliking booke comon prayer pretende cause misliking nowe ioyne defacing ouerthrowing followeth word thing whiche reproue booke godly moste bettered person stande defense booke haue poyntes papistrie great detestation peraduenture greater occupie themselues externall thinges small importance meane time theythe admonitors gratifie papist slippe ouer matter weighte substance euen principall poyntes differ wherefore comparison standeth vpon false grounde fully persuaded doo pope great good seruice woulde misse thing desire haue churche englande whiche hathe accursed vtterly defaced discredited haue meanes ouerthrowne forreyne enimies yet domesticall dissention fitter apter instrumentes coulde haue purpose vnder pretence zeale ouerthrowe whiche men haue buylded vnder colour puritie seeke bring deformitie vnder cloke equalitie humilitie would vsurpe great tyrannie ouer page ii sect touching name title putteth difference wordes called gratious lordes shall vvith argument may framed forasmuche seuered title ciuill minister doth agree title gracious lordes therefore ecclesiasticall minister dothe agree fitte whose office carrie outewarde maiestie pompe shoulde haue name agreeable magnificence meete god hathe remoued pompe outwarde shewe shoulde lykewyse bee remoued suche swellyng loftye title doe agree simplicitie ministerie whiche exercise whereas myghte seeme somewhat vniust hath greater giftes shoulde preferred whiche haue lesse sauiour christe sheweth matter farre otherwyse muche euery man dothe excell fellowe gift holye ghost muche ought employe himselfe benefyte others maner shoulde become theyr seruaunt doo good whiche although parte common ciuill magistrate minister worde yet dothe neuer lette downe hymself lowe giueth seruice eyther churche common wealth dothe ought seruice retayne dignitie countenaunce markes note therof whiche princely estate dothe require ende propoundeth hymselfe example whome setteth theyr eye perfecte paterne ministe line seeyng beeyng lorde tooke vpon hym seruant beyng emperour kyng heauen earth content want glorie shewe worlde ministerie requiryng shoulde great shame whiche disciple chosen ministerie content themselues aspire vnto suche office dignity dreamed io whitgifte saye christ place conclude though cocke sure pray tell whervpon gather christ maketh distinction eyther office title deede woulde haue difference bothe betwixte authoritie disciple christian dominion heathenishe prince affection whiche ruled chryste vseth call backe bee errours corrupt affection example gentile doth mathew much carefulnesse meate drink lyke nam omnia ista gens exquirunt thing gentils seeke dothe corrupt affection desiring touchying argument saye hath two faultes fyrst fallaciontwo faultes argument c petitione principij take graunted ciuill magistrate seuered ecclesiasticall officer bearyng dominion whyche simplye graunte vnto partely oure question secondly minor ambiguousthe ciuill magistrate doth simply biffer ecclesiastical bearing dominion therfore respect argumente may also placed fallacion aequiuocation worde dominion may haue diuers signification may signifye suche dominion christe speaketh place rule oppression maye also signifie absolute authoritie prince suche mentioned samuell thyrdely maye signifie peculiar office superioritie gouernment vnder prince appoyntment prince thediuers signification word dominion authoritie iudge iustice maior c laste may signifye iurisdiction kynde gouernment take eyther two fyrst signification minor true either two latter signification false wee graunte greate difference betwixte dominion king prince betwixte jurisdiction authoritie bishoppes king haue power ouer lyfe goodes c haue bishop king haue authoritiie al cause ouer person withintheir dominion without limitation bishop haue suche dominion especially ciuill cause respect bishop prince limited vnto touching theyr name title saye putteth difference woordes called gracious lordes shall c woordes twentith mathewe bee greate exercise authoritie ouer marke woordes vsed luke greeke woorde nonlatin alphabet benefici vocantur called bountifull beneficiall whyche see howe anye meanes applye purpose mathewe marke referre thys clause shall bee among anye name ambition tyrannicall kynde dominion whyche sauioure christe reproueth moste manyfeste therefore thys place luke muste also bee expounded neither woorde nonlatin alphabet suche imperiousnesse chryste shoulde forbydcaluinus hys disciple name caluine commentary interpretyng woordes saincte luke sayeth thus touchyng woordes mathewe hath king exercise authoritie ouer luke wee reade called bountyfull worthy noted epistle ad casulanum sayth thus rebus de quibus nihil certi statuit scriptura diuina mo populi dei vel instituta maiorum pro lege tenenda sunt thyngs vvherein holy scripture hathe determined certainetie custome people god tradition decree forefather holden lavve whereby manifest thing maye retained churche whych expressed scripture epistle reporteth aunswere ambrose made vnto hym beyng demaunded whether lawfull faste sabboth daye faste seyng among church diuersitie thys poyut quando bic sum sayth non ie line uno idem sabbato quando romae sum ieiuno sabbato ad quamcunque ecclesiam veneritis eius morem seruate si pati scandalum non vultis aut facere vvhen faste sabboth vvhen rome doe faste sabboth churche euer come keepe custome thereof vvill neyther suffer offence good learned man rather beleeued long repugnant worde god althoughe best earth bringeth forth weedes yet good fruite muste weedes sake refused meane reason good men sometimes erre deceiued therefore must neuer thing beleeued come purpose say fyrst place saint augustine nothing agaynst thing holde c surely maketh wholly holde proueth directly thing wherein scripture hath determyned certaintie cause required constrayned spoken peraduenture enough doe resiste byshoppe herein followe whyche dothe wythout scruple doubte wherefore saint augustyne sayth mo populi dei c hys meanyng obserued rule keepe priuate particular men order quiet obedience churche althoughe deedethe church may alter order generally obserued without iust cause churche selfe maye wythoute iuste cause chaunge suche thyngs haue beene generally obserued beyng contra fidem bonos more agaynst faythe good manner lordes daye daye resurrection ascention suche lyke maye iuste cause thyngs determyned churche shoulde chaunged afterwardes thoughe thyngs arbitrarye myghte haue beene otherwyse manner decreed churche thoughte moste conuenient suche cause maye alter anye vse ceremonye order whiche hathe determyned saynt contra fidem bonos more wythin compasse thys rule augustine perceyue repugnancie betwixte ambrose augustyne ignatius andthe replyer setteth father together eares without cause tertullian sabboth daye mentioned ambrose augustyne lordes daye whych call sundaye whereof ignatius tertullian speake saterday whych called sabbatum true myghte haue read epistle augustyne casulanus saith thus vvhereas aske whyther lawfull faste sabboth daye iibidem aunswere meanes lawfull truely neyther moyses helias oure lorde selfe woulde haue fasted fortie dayes together thys reason concluded faste lordes daye lawfull also notwythstandyng whosoeuer doth thynke thys daye oughte dedicated vnto fastyng doe obserue sabboth fasting shall gyue small offence churche epistle truely sabboth day case easie bycause woulde seeme father agree among selues haue faulted opposyng augustyne ambrose anye thing yet proued agaynst man may well vse theyr authoritie matter wythout inconuenience suppose knowe howe farre place first haue omitted wordes going expresse mynde declare meaneth suche ceremony impedimentes obseruing god commaundementes hauing spoken suche manyfest wordes concludeth haue sayde sort omnia ita que talia c suche ceremony c whiche word haue fraudulently kept backe secondly augustine speaketh vnreasonable multitude ceremony vsing wordes innumerabiliter variantur varied innumerably haue likwyse lefte word innumerably also expresseth augustine meaning laste haue concealed sentence middest whiche materiall declaring augustine minde sentence ita vt vix aut omnino nunquam inueniri possint causae quas eis instituendis homines secuti sunt scarcely neuer cause founde oute whiche men followed appoynting whereby playne also meaneth suche ceremony bee appoynted without reason cause yet latter ende addeth churche god beeing placed betwixte muche chaffe darnell dothe tollerate many thinges c farre defending multitude burdensomnesse ceremony consent poyntes saying augustine wherefore sentence nothing hotte pleaseth righte well bin commendation medled withall whose name heere recite thoughe haue written wordes yet place whiche haue qnoted doe affirme muche recite whiche might haue founde taken paynes searche thinke verily haue done founde little purpose therfore content passe ouer silence make ofte repetitinons doe occasioned whome answere selfe replie though pleaseth acknowne sentence doctor writer stuffe argue haue red ashamed lay open ende playne dealing may seene alledging fynde faulte dumbe doctor nowe abyde speaking surely intend directed vnconstant guyde proue thing man denyeth hadde lesse laboure replying translate whole leaues small purpose sooner answered vpon lighte occasion haue made often digression take heede well assured offende lyke truly haue forgotten place digression without reason let reuerende modeste speaches passe recompence lyke neither sauoureth spirite god neither yet modest good nature stomack swelling rather person cause purpose place moses law whiche doth meanes punish exod short al thing must transformedexod lawyer must cast away huge volume multitude case content selues bookes moses cleargie would best iudges must require lawe though punishment death according law moses appoynted adultriecyrill certayne crime yet among christian suche commaundement force musculus common place tit de legib speaking law sayth thusmuscul aske commaundementes haue ceassed euident forsomuche priesthoode lawe ceremony annexed abrogated priesthoode christ according order melchizedech iudicials also ceassed dothe herein appeare whole order gouernment israell requisite vnto inhabiting lande promise hath time ceassed wh line beeing expelled began dwell amongst gentile without king without gouernours without priest without lawe hemingius encber iudgement word alsohemingius iudiciall law expired common wealth moses dothe binde man necessitie farre onely portion dothe perteyne law nature law agaynst incestuous mariages leuit much saith temporall exercise keepe people obedience c booke speaking deut graue image god shalldeut ye burne fire couet siluer golde c saith althoughe politike lawe giuen onely auncient people time yet hereby may gather detestable idolatrie c place moste euident hathe institu cap sect therfore wil rehearse large sunt qui recte compositam rempub negent c certaine denie thatcaluinus common welth well ordered omitting politike lawes moses ruled common lawes gentile opinion dangerous seditious let men cosider inough haue declared false foolish vsuall diuision obserued deuideth whole law god deliuered moses maners ceremony iudgements euery part therof diligently considered may vnderstande perteyneth vnto v thereof dothe meane time let man troubled iudicials ceremony apperteyne vnto maners ancient father inuentors diuisio although ignorant two latter part occupied maners yet bycause might altered abrogated without preiudice vnto maners called morall called first part properly name moral without true holynesse maners immutable rule liuing could well consist agayne law god forbiddeth steale punishment appoynted thefte pollicie iewes appeareth exod moste auncient lawes nationsexod face speake wherein consent wherevpon writer accorde outwarde markes wherby true christian church knowne preaching worde purely ministring sacramentes sincerely ecclesiasticall discipline consisteth admonition correcting faultes seuerely touching first namely ministerie worde althougher must confessed substance doctrine many deliuered sounde good yet herein fayleth neither minister thereof accordyng god worde proued elected called ordained function sorte narrowly loked vnto right ought necessitie required ansvvere admonition pag proposition libellers woulde proue englande farre hauyng churche rightly reformed accordyng prescripte god worde yet come outwarde face proofe hereof vse argnment three warde markes whereby true christian churche knowen preaching worde purely ministryng sacramentes sincerely ecclesiasticall discipline whiche consisteth admonition correction faultes seuerely thys church englande effecte saye voyde ergo hath much externall face church proue worde god preached truely reason thys sort minister worde according god worde proued elected called ordeyned function suche sort narrowly loked vnto right ought necessitie required therfore word god truely preached hereall pointes doctrine pure church thankes god alleage one article faith poynte doctrine one peece substance otherwise taughte allowed thys churche euery mannes folly ascribed whole churche prescripte worde god may iustified neyther nowe howe conclusion followeth though antecedent true let iudge learned minister rightly proued elected vnapt r line son ergo worde god truely preached howe wicked euer man howsoeuer intrude hymselfe ministerie yet maye preache true worde god truthe doctrine dothe anye respecte depende vpon goodnesse euilnesse man praye howe adherentes called elected c come purpose woulde proue minister worde church englande accordyng god worde proued elected called ordeyned force pithe argumentes shall appeare seuerall answeres euery one one thing muste let vnderstande men seeke deface thys churche englande selfe groundes papistes doe althoughe another kynde proofe haue papistes else saye haue minister bycause rightly called consequently worde sacramentes discipline churche certainely well examyned beleeue woulde fall oute author booke haue conspired papistes ouerthrowe coulde state churche realme howsoeuer subtilly seeme detest papistrie c page sect say effecte doe saye churche englande voyde preachyng ministring sacramentes one saye worde churche englande purely preached sacramentes sincerely discipline seuerely administred wyth thys churche englande voyde agayne doe reason thus worde god truely preached bycause minister ryghtly proued elected haue one worde true preachyng one saye purely preached saye truely preached saynte paule thea cauill philipp gladde gospell preached althoughe purely woulde neuer haue gladde haue preached falsely truely againe inueygheth agaynst false apostle churche corinthe bycause preached worde vntruely bycause vsyng paynted word affected eloquence makyng great shewe learnyng tounges dyd preache gospell sincerely see one thyng preache truely thing preache purely see reason euill want good calling maye gyue occasion saye worde god sincerely taughte bycause lawfull ordinarie calling althoughe substaunce doctrine manner handlyng sainte paule speaketh philipp dyd faulte yet saynt paule sayth dyd preache purely bycause dyd contention enuie whyche faulte doctrine hym taughte therefore let men iudge howe iuste wayghtes expounde purely truely whyther thys confute men argumentes rather skirmishe wyth owne shadowes knowe papistes reason thus bycause haue minister therefore worde sacrament discipline churche denie haue worde sacramentes bycause holde worde sacrifice reason yet men charge haue neither antecedent consequent neuer sayde ministerie england yet euer conclude word sacrament discipline churche saying face churche dothe muche appeare whole proces booke dothe declare meane say haue scarce face churche graunte haue churche god wante ornamentes whiche shoulde haue throughe certayne deformed ragges poperie whiche shoulde haue churche dothe appeare hir natiue colour beautifull meete shoulde prepared glorious husbande sonne god say certaynely beleeue author booke conspired papistes ouerthrowe churche realme nowe certaynely neuer doe iniurie vnto goe purge manyfest slaunders neuer broughte outrage speech proue nooneday mydnight therefore set conscience togither reader desire thinke straunge thing hath happened seruaunts god euen haue professed religion whiche dyd appeareth ieremie whiche accused certayne israelite conspired babilonians mortall enimyes layd charge goyng going beniamin io whitgifte blynde see doe plaine wordes saye outwarde markes whereby true christian churche knowen preaching worde purely ministring sacramentes sincerely ecclesiasticall discipline c whole drifte admonition proue neither worde preached purely sacramentes sincerely ministred c chnrche englande doet c willuigly peruerteth word ye answere otherwyse reporte wordes playne doe affirme shoulde saye churche englande voyde preaching ministring sacramentes let reader consider wordes accordingly iudge plaine dealing write yt effect say church england voyde sure referre whiche went preaching worde purely ministring sacramentes sincerely ecclesiasticall discipline c neither otherwise doe thoughe woulde wrest wordes neuer violently therefore reporte say church england neither hath worde purely preached sacramentes sincerely ministred c make greate difference betwixte purely truely neyther dothe followepurely truely worde god truely preached alwayes truth preached man maye doe iusta iuste lust thyngs yet iustly maye truthe preached yet truely man maye doe whiche iuste vnwittingly gayne pleasure malice dothe iustly quid non ex babitu animo euen man maye preache true worde god affection contention ambition profite c dothe preache truely distinction knowne therefore texte without discretion alleaged proue oughte tryall theyr abilitie instruct c bene quoted proue suche admitted function meete bothe sor lyfe doctrine bene purpose thynke necessarye suche bee admitted ministerie vnlesse bee verye well knowne shoulde tryed bothe learning lyfe place maketh nothing purpose rather contrarie speaketh suche two well knowne therefore needed tryall wee conclude thyng place muste bee none oughte bee admitted ministerie suche well knowne neede tryall cause presentyng whyche expressed texte presumption make scripture serue maynteyn oure contention agaynste expresse woords playn meaning thys rule followed muste followed wholly haue learned adde take lawe rule prescribed god woorde howe doe ye knowe example must followed one thing speciall reuelation haue make suche dismembring action doubte thys example extraordinarie necessitie bee followed woordes caluine playne certaine rule gathered example electing minister bicause calling apostle greatnesse forgyuenesse bothe thoughe diuersely louyng kindnesse god remayneth according lawe example adulterer adultresse weare punnyshed wyth presente deathe muche bothe haue suffered punishment sinne haue receiued due rewarde wickednesse committed reuengement shall afterward hang ouer soules haue committed fault sinne may condemne onely haue committed fact haue receiued punishment due lawe lord punishe one thing twise haue receiued rewarde sinne paine offence finished cause kind commaundement cruell heretikes affirme accusing lawe god denying kinde humanitie full mercie bycause hereby people rather purged sinnes condemned nowe punishment layd vpon body purging sinne corporall punishment repentance man doe worthily worke may seme worthie haue punishment withdrawne maye finde commaundement god repugnant according threatenings god scripture pronouced see lesser fault man punished greater torment euen according state euery cou try smelleth one whitte manichee heresie cleane magistratet c vnder pretence pusheth ciuill magistrate vnder pretence speakyng agaynst state ecclesiasticall howesoeuer woulde seeme bryng place eighteenth exodus proue phrase manner speaking yet maye bee thoughte secretely insinuate prince maye appoynte vnderofficers without election people surely dealing place bee well marked may easily seene reasonyng agaynst gouernemente churche laye groundes keepe selfe running maruell suche high speaches voyde truth first say translation hath ordeyned minister without making mention election haue gayned thereby shewe moe translate otherwise say ordeyned hand vsed word signifieth lyfting vp handes would haue vsed word signifying holding vp laying downe handes layde heade layde downe holden vp woordes olde testamente newe luke wrote wrote expresse thys ceremonie laying hand yet none haue euer expressed saincte paule speaketh thrise epistle timothie alwayes hee vseth1 tim tim tim nonlatin alphabet olde testamente ceremonie vsed spoken septuaginta nonlatin alphabet woorde whyche saincte paule vseth septuaginta althoughe holye ghoste speake proprely well whome soeuer speaketh yet coulde haue bene worste sayde saincte luke canonicall writer hee shoulde speake thus vnproprely wryteth moste purely elegantely accordyng phrase moste eloquent grecian therefore hee borrowed thys speache auncient greeke wryters whyche dyd vse expresse theyr election thys worde bycause made voyces giuen ceremonie lyftyng vp handes saincte luke haue vsed worde thys booke signification choosyng voyce dare saye vseth putting hand actes sainct peter sayth writer c truely doe stande muche owne conceyte neyther well persuaded owne witte vnderstanding greatly esteeme opinion learned men thinke selfe haue reason sufficient haue good learned authoritie grounded vpon scripture reason put doubte offended bicause doe must offended still rather alleage authoritie learned men whiche grounded bothe vpon scripture reason sticke mine owne phansie bothe without authoritie reason commonly doe whiche desirous innouations haue heades filled new deuises take view reason c first examine reason seuerally answere owne examination reason c vseth proue perpetuall equitie c election people chap diuision c pag sect sayde amongest lawyer deede reason law nation confirmeth quod omnium interest ab omnibus approbari debet standeth men vppon shoulde approued men whiche lawe hath sense may good thinges whiche shall binde men whiche require obedience shoulde concluded farre may consent least consent many may gotten therefore draweth muche obedience subiectes realme statute whereby realme gouerned passe consent moste parte whilest made whome rest put trust choose purpose beeing actes io whitgifte vse purpose rule lawe whiche doe vnderstande interest thing haue thing common whereof euery hathe priuate interest right propertie euery man consent house thing common among halfe dosen men purchase discent gifte fiue would burden thing charge body politike body whole common wealth citie borough towne colledge churche c wherein lawyer say rule hathe force reason lawe bicause beeing almoste impossible thing men suche body agree one beeing obserued wherefore rule hathe onely place seconde thinges arethis law take holde election minister common pluribus vt singulis many seuerally wherein euery man hathe proprietie particular righte haue spoken large antract place causeth fall many grosse erroures concernyng saye ciuile magistrate head churche c christethe prince head church onely properly head churche hys body yet respecte externall societie supreme authoritie gyuen god prince ouer people cause maye bee also respecte called head churche c chrysostom epistol ad philip homel gyueth thys name certaine womenchrysost whome sayeth thus videntur mibi istae mulieres caput fuisse ecclesiae quae illic erat woman seeme mee haue bin head churche therfore learned answering hosius reproued vergerius mouing yt kingiaco andraea polonia take vopen hym head churche sayeth thys sorte churche christ earth one bodie hathe one head apostle teacheth iesus christe always present churche gouerneth holie spirite c bicause church visible onely ruled worde sworde magistrate also appointed god therefore wee saye manie heades church gouernours countreys see magistrate head chief gouernour particular church respect visible societie must haue besides spirituall externall gouernment also whereof bicause ciuill magistrate head chief therefore therin established without ciuil magistrate spare speches authoritie magistrate gouernment church note seuerall place themselues therfore doe lyghtlyer passe ouer place meane tyme good argument saye magistrate member churche therefore heade chiefe gouernoure thereof earth head though chiefe yet parte bodie still confounde visible inuisible churche christe spirituall externall gouernment confusion maye make seeme say something suche doe diligently consider deede say nothing ouerthrowe thing haue answered churche may established without magistrate touching true faith spirituall gouernment christe hearte conscience manhow yt church may established without magistrate touching visible societie externall gouernment upon confusion also grounded whiche followeth churche respect christ head monarchie c sayde state churche popular apostle tyme spake outward forme shewe gouernment therefore call popular bycause churche selfe whole multitude interest almost euery thing especially whylest churche yet remained ierusalem knowe three kyndes gouernmentes maye bee mixte together dyuers sortes yet state gouernment named according whiche moste ruleth beareth greatest sway matter moste commonly gouerned consent parte people state called popular diuers best wysest called optimorum status one called monarchie thys realme courte parliamente althoughe state represented yet bycause iudgemente confirmation determination resteth prince therefore state neyther aristocratie democratie monarchie euen apostle time especiallye haue sayde whylest churche remayned hierusalem thoughe myghte counted optimates yet bycause moste thyngs gouernmente doone consente people therefore state tyme popular saye shoulde haue shewed howe thys difference hauyng christian magistrate hauyng none oughte bryng diuersitie choyse pastor church haue shewed reason nowe adde muche magistrate illiricus haue borrowed dothe otherwyse quote place nowebeit wordes illiricus dothe reporte whiche thinke taken glossa ordinaria make nothing agaynst thing haue sayde thus reason bishop must ordeyne ergo may elect denie argument reason haue shewed one man may bothe ordeyne elect haue vtterly falsified hieromes wordes ad rusticum monachum muchet c falsifieth hierome declined true interpretation woulde haue suspected especially seeing woulde thoughte haue intrapped like long wordes hierome cum ad perfectam aetatem veneris si tamen hier ad rustic monachum vita come fuerit te vel populus vel pontifex ciuitatis clerum elegerit agito quae clerici sunt vvhen thou shalte come perfecte age thy lyfe answerable eyther people bishop citie shall choose thee cleargie doe suche thinges belong clearke dothe heere people shoulde haue authoritie choose clearks minister saye saythe vnto rusticus monke eyther people bishop citie choose clearke must doe thinges perteyne clearke sayth vel populus mode doe expressely signifie commaundement bishop may wel say sea rageth line elleth peace quiet say receiue holy ghost thinke good reason vse making minister bicause vse word sauiour christ may well requisite function heape vp iudgement writer knowe thinke might easily done liked follow waye io whitgifte christ vsed wordes bodye celebration supper speciall commaundement minister vse yet must vse b line cause christ vsed euen christ ordeine apostle minister gospell io sayd vnto receiue holy g line ost c word bicause containe principall duetie minister signifie god doth poure spirit vpon calleth function aptly also vsed bishop god instrument businesse ordeyning minister paule speaking timothie tim saythe neglecte1 tim gifte thee whiche giuen vnto thee prophecie laying handes eldership whiche wordes apostle signifieth god dothe bestowe giftes spirite vpon suche called ministerie worde whereof imposition handes token rather confirmation therfore sayth caluine vayne ceremonie bicause god dyd fulfill hyscal tim spirite consecration men dyd signifie imposition handes surely vayne ceremonie though done men vayne word though spoken men neither dothe bishop speake thoughe authoritie giue holy ghost speaketh word christ vsed like action sayde dothe moste certaynly giue holy spirite calleth ministerie surely patterne eyther calling ordeyning minister followed christ followed romaine corinthian galatian church whome wrote yet continually resident among apostle preacher whiche resident one place yet preacher may good preaching among whome knoweth god directeth word matter muche cannot knowe euery congregation consisteth diuers mindes affection therefore excepte voyde discretion moderate temper hys sermon exhortation may profyte hurte none suche accordingly receyue therefore bothe proposition false th line man preaching cannot profyte knoweth cannot know except perpetually resident chap sixte diuision c page sect moreouer law priest ready temple answer al doubt question people come aske minister seuerall parish shoulde ready dissolue difficulty eyther one hathe another himselfe touching conscience want whereof conscience many doubtfull daungerous wrastling deuill wich dispaire strangled therevpon hang drowne themselues putting away care conscience sinning labouring haue sense feeling sinne close vp wounde vnhealed eyther breaketh daungerously else euery day waxing senselesse withoute feeling treasure vp vnto themselues wrath god day iudgement although iudgement god doth time follow hard terroure conscience vntaught vncomforted kill themselues yet estate neuer lesse daungerous therefore rather asmuch longer line sinne drawne also pull vpon themselues heauier conde line nation thing see oftentimes eye consider easy iudge commeth passe great condemned onely author booke zuinfildians c page sect vlt pag sect beget father many bookes child like eldest brother would without better aduise shake many groundes religion heere agayne wishe pastor able teache beeing vnpossible state nowe content pastor minister doe nothing reade throughout whole booke make maruellous good estate alwayes turne best side outwarde men goe vrge deformity thereof ende mighte remedied lay open shame nakednesse make greater deede haue shewed church standeth muche neede reading minister would make worlde beleeue although great deformitie sore plague churche whiche speake confesse vnwares yet let man come neare heale make gayne sore sore legges therefore haue medicine keepe woundes alwayes greene heale hope purpose keepe churche estate dare say chiefe gayne honour consisteth grounded ruines churche therefore desire tooke vnto io whitgifte omit whatsoeuer heere speake agaynst person purposed absteinethe cause lacke able minister requiting like sorte onely answere selfe labour slaunder cause lacke sufficient number meete minister church neyther religion professed gouernment vsed yet gouernours partly crueltie time past wherein number meete minister haue bin consumed partly vn willingnesse present time haue zeale enter calling wished partly nay chiefly principally schismes haue caused cast ministerie wholly forsake pastorall charge yet keepe prebendes liuings depraue ministerie condemne meanes possible alienate many therefore nothing confesse scarsitie meete able minister derogateth thing eyther doctrine professed church fro kinde gouernment magistrate rather comendeth bicause notwithstanding al former impediment yet hath number excellent minister doth continually breed mo confession tende condemnation adherent haue hindred slaundered gospel realme england papist eyther haue done could possibly fully persuaded one greatest deformity suffered church lacke discipline towardes farre healing sore church suffered greater doe wounde deede reformation pretende nothing meere confusion rather subuersion bothe churche common wealthe also honour gaine verie small yet worthie trust tyme come boyling affection vttered spitefull maner made manyfest pray god imputed vnto day houour gayne may stande good prosperous estate churche readie yelde vp whensoeuer shall due authoritie required meane tyme god iudge betwixt chap diuision c page sect estate church suche speake scarce yeeld three preaching pastor bishop diocesse may therfore make reading minister deed apostle made councell commaundement pastor church able teache saying might haue bene borne seyng paule hath commaunded expressedly able teache andtim conuince gaynsayers would learne gladly necessitie whiche cantit cause man breake morall law god bring tradition man may wel break commaundement god necessity sake breake comprehended fyrst table tosay reade must tolerated church minister say bycause haue pastor church haue idolls doubt call although ignorance whiche may good men yet respect place occupie idolls stand make shew whiche admit often lorde pronounceth shall minister haue knowledgeqzee let v heare reason youre owne reason must reading church therfore must minister whiche doe nothing else may reason thus muste breaking bread distributyng cuppe church pouring water therfore whosoeuer able breake aloafe bread lift cup wine poure water bodye chylde may made minister neuer reade yt reader church reading minister reading scripture prayer church wyll fitter place speake afterward shal shewed vniustly surmise thing touching homily shal spoken hereafter occasion giuen io whitgifte sainct paule tim tit sheweth quality bishop pastor ought haue doth say none founde sufficient number whome quality concurre church shal rather destitute minister haue suche time swarued rule yet glad preached minister churche england though diuerse ignorant yet inaye studye diligente readyng scripture catechismes homily godlie necessarie bookes profyte thys churche englande poynt professeth nothing allowed generall confession church heluetia whiche thinke dissente confession tolde hathe woordes vve condemne vnmete minister indued giftes necessarie reiect nowadays good simplicitie certain bee altogether vnskilfull god worde nothing ozee serueth turne say reason thus muste bee readyng churche therefore muste bee minister doe nothyng else knowe christian magistrate may enioyne seuerall kinde apparell minister eyther cause weake whiche defende else hathe gotten euill patrone whiche would gladly shifte chaunge another question whiche speake although graunted vnto whiche demaunde yet conclude cause albeit magistrate may commaunde seuerall apparell yet followeth may commaunde kinde popishe apparell therfore manner argument magistrate maye commaunde seuetall apparell therefore maye commaunde colledge walles tell mighte haue learned logike within colledge walles man conclude whole parte affirmatiuely see mighte let fishe catche nothing neyther afrayde ashamed tell truthe aske farre foorthe leaft perswaded much say like may vse thinke therefore maye suche kinde apparell magistrate commaunding minister may refuse suche may may refuse whatsoeuer apparell commaundement without iniurie done minister seeing magistrate may say like iudges doth allow wise learned discrete man trusteth gouernment people matter betweene god somewhat hard trust appoynting owne apparel probably supposed hathe discretion weare owne geare comely order able teache others howe shoulde weare shoulde able doe wisedome learning others doe without learning great store wysedome keepe order decencie apparell hath learned schole christe whiche doe neuer scholemaster common sense reason minister founde faulte going eyther dissolutely exquisitely delicately magistrate maywhy may aswell appoynt order punishe disorder line punishe according disorder wherin saulteth io whitgifte noted order delte sincerely wordes might lesse discredite vnto haue bin well forborne place onely proue minister may distinguished seuerall kinde apparell aske question whether christian magistrate may appoynt seueral kind apparell order decencie apparell whiche admonition calleth antichristian speake little vsuall kinde reasoning ad idem argueth lacke abilitie answere present purpose question incident cause christian magistrate haue authoritie appoynt seuerall kinde apparell minister also lawfull minister vse saye colledge walles tell man cannot conclude whole thean argument holdeth whole part affirmatiuely somtune parte affirmatiuely althoughe argument neyther genere toto ab oppositis relatiuis effecte magistrate may commaunde ergo subiects must obey yet colledge walles dumbe speake rule logike telleth whole meane whiche logitians doe call genus argument whole parte doth firmely holde affirmatiuely whole taken vniuersaliter vniuersally example omne animal est sensibile ergo omnis bomo est sensibilis omnis virtu est mediocritas ergo temperantia est mediocritas likewyse magistrate hath authoritie appoynt kinde habite order decencie ergo maye appoynt kinde habite meane whole whiche logitians doe properly call tum integrale seeme doe rule logike tell ab omn line line oto ad partes excepte toto modo argument good affirmatiuely otherwise disposed boaste knowledge logike winne opinion thereof selfe defacing contemning thanke god haue sufficient maynteyne whatsoeuer haue written answere replie contrarie would haue thought spirite bin c man supposed mortified cthe magistrate authoritie appoin ting apparellabridged c answere question deede good neuer whitte neuer deale better suche sorte giue magistrate authoritie commaunde kinde apparell minister commaunde none vnto whatsoeuer without iniurie done minister whiche verye straunge answere first restrayneth magistrate hauing authoritie kinde apparell suche saye maye minister maye refuse dothe accuse magistrate iniurie appoynte euen kinde apparell maye lawfully doe saye whatsoeuer apparell commaundement without iniurie done minister nyce authoritie giuen magistrate let reader well consider wordes marke authoritie giue magistrate one reason whereby woulde proue magistrate line minister iniurie commaunde weare kinde apparell whiche lawfull commaunded magistrate dothe allowe wise learned discrete man c therefore somewhat harde trust appoynting owne apparell c first true magistrate dothe allowe c wyll haue chosen parishe magistrate knowe kinde minister euery parishe dothe choose secondly magistrate allowe vpon condition obedient lawes thirdly magistrate may deceyued take another manner man laste howe wyse howe learned howe discrete soeuer yet meete obey lawes subiecte vnto good order may learned wyse discrete men alleadge selues also say able gouerne themselues neede lyke child prescribed doe vndoubtedly day voyce diuers lesson libertie belike haue learned doe moste humbly desire haue care common wealthe butwherevnto assertion tendeth consider lyeth hidde euen wordes vttered place doubte vnderstande seeke freedome lawes prince imagine suche perfection maye men shall neede gouerned ciuill lawes euery man lawe selfe heere subtile dealing worthy noted whiche vsuall altering case whereas kynde apparell appoynted distinction men externall note calling sortes men iudges sergeantes alderman c though line knewe make reader beleeue magistrate appoynting apparell dothe mistrust minister discretion wearing owne geare comely order meaning magistrate commaundement heerein minister shoulde goe eyther dissolutely disorderly rather minister shoulde vse fourme decent apparell whereby mighte one vniforme order agree amongest selues differ state people hir dominion ment vprightly woulde often deale order chap diuision ansvvere admonition pag sect iudges sergeant alderman citizen knowne apparell maye minister likewyse vnder subiection subiect ciuill lawes ordinance ought obey gouernours thing agaynst worde god c pag sect whereas woulde proue maye done minister done wyth iudges sergeantes alderman sheriffes case lyke office robe gownes may mace swordes somewhat helpe set foorthe maiestie moderate pompe whiche meete office iustice whiche execute consequently helpe strike profitable feare heart whiche vnderneath whiche hathe haue place minister whose authoritie power outwarde ought borrowe credite externall shewes magistrate citie may seeke honor citizen mustering number one liuerie whiche ought looked minister hande honoreth serueth magistrate waye also considering scattered throughe lande euery towne one many beeing put one liuerie would make great shewe honour commendation towne citie remayne io whitgifte mighte well answere iudges sergeant c doe minister saye seeing magistrate dothe allowe wyse learned discrete men trusteth gouernment common wealthe somethyng harde trust appoynting owne apparell shoulde reason fondly seditiously meete learned wyse discrete men subiecte lawes wyser learneder discreeter willing obey kinde argument tendeth nothing else animating subiects agaynst magistrate agaynst lawesthe subiects line nated magistrate thoughe authoritie minister oughte haue muste come especially doctrine good conuersation calling yet outwarde meanes beeing lawfull refused whereby maye helped muste labour muche euen outwarde meanes whether conuersation apparell suche lyke thing commende office calling procure reuerence vnto man mighte lykewyse saye prince iudges magistrate reuerenced apparell sake authoritie committed vnto god yet meete conuenient weare suche kinde apparell may externally commende authoritie apparell minister declareth modestie grauitie signifieth calling office perteyneth comelynesse order therefore conuenient prescribed vnto kinde apparell iudges sergeantes ciuill magistrate forasmuche minister member common wealthe meete shoulde subiecte order honor prince haue state degree person within hir dominion good order citie towne togither separate therefore nothing say magistrate citie maye seeke honor citizen c iudge wheresoeuer goeth ought knowne apparel euen minister neyther shewe good reason contrarie caluine vponcaluine mat sayth meete doctor grauitie modestie apparell differ common sorte chap diuision c pag sect see question answered whereby appeareth subiectes obey also sometimes commaundement giuen vpon good ground io whitgifte answered deede according expectation neyther according truthe duetie subiect distinction apparell appoynted minister pope tyrannie chap diuision ansvvere admonition pag sect doubte whether particular kinde apparell differing lay men euer appoynted minister church pope tyrannie whether dayes maye appoynted reformed church heare iudgement master bullinger master gualter epistle written master n master word auncient churche vvas particular fashion apparellbullinger gualter priest appeareth ecclesiasticall historie theodoret lib cap socrates lib cap man ignorante vvhich hath lightly redde ouer monumentes auncient father minister vsed cloake seruice therefore say de diuersitie garmentes originall pope eusebius citeth auncient vvryters sainct iohn apostle vvare head leafe thinne plate lyke vnto bishop myter pontius diaconus vvitnesseth sainct cyprian martyr vvhen offered necke executioner first gaue cappe deacon vpper garment stode appareled vvhite linnen moreouer chrysostome maketh mention vvhyte apparell minister seruice seuerall apparell minister common christian chaunge religion chaunged also apparell appeareth manifestly tertullian de pailio petalum iohn ware see howe proued like bishop line iter cappe cyprian gaue executioner argueth rather common apparell whiche customably worne else woulde haue done muche good vpper garment whiche gaue deacon token good wyll would leaue practise hath beene buiusmodi data potestate euertuntur quamuis manifestum est cum id agimus non ea no honorare sed potius detestari ideo tamen vsus nostros priuatos duntaxat proprios non debemus inde aliquid vsurpare vt appareat no pietate ista destruere non auaritia cum vero vsus commune non proprios ac priuatos vel honorem dei veri conuertuntur hoc de illis fit quod de ipsis hominibus cum ex sacrilegis impijs veram religionem mutantur c vvhen temple idol groues like thing authoritie ouerthrovvne althoughe manifest vvhen vvedoe vve honourpriuate vse idolatrous thing forbidden detest yet vve may therefore conuert vse ovvne priuate v onely commoditie may appeare vve destroy religion sake couetousnesse vvhen conuerted priuate ovvne vse common v honor true god done brought passe vvhich done brought passe men selues whe idolater vvicked person chaunged true religio hath god himselfe taught testimony vvhich thou thy selfe haste vsed vvhen god himselfe commaunded groue vvhich vvas dedicated straunge god shoulde wood taken sacrifice hierico golde siluer brasse shoulde brought treasurie lorde vvherefore also vvhich vvritten deutronomie thou shalt couet siluer golde neyther shalt thou take thing therof thy selfe least thou offende bycause abhomination vnto lord thy god c manifestly appearreth eyther priuate v forbydden thing nothing brought thy house honored abhomination c hetherto augustine wordes doth manifestly appeare euen thing altogetheridolatrous thing turned comon vse dedicated idol vsed idolatrie may conuerted common v vsed seruice god honor priuate v superstitiously c pag sect augustine place vnderstanded thing haue shift answered ward necessarie vse therefore may taken away v superstition men might also depriued sunne life worlde bycause sunne hath bene worshipped saint augustine like kinde reteining ceremony maye shift answered ward appeare aske saith paganes may wonne may brought saluationaugust line om de verbis domini mattheum line forsake solemnity let go toyes idolatrous seruice also giue occasion papistes thinke better theyr masse bycause see frequented suche seeme professe gospell thereby also persuade selues greater multitude embraceth religion wherefore one way conuert absteine church may vnderstand misliking theyr seruice owne paucitie also ment augustine place may also appeare wordes sermon paganes saye heartes forsake god seeing christian selues worship well agayne beholde true god thou doest offende whyles thou fallest downe false god augustine speaketh one worde sermon ceremony thing else taken gentils christian conuerted v muche lesse suche matter haue newe question therfore abuse reader reciting certaine word augustine without circumstance open true meaning praise wit saying thing may conuerted priuate v denie augustine plainely doth shall bound vnto doctrine shall haue fewer fautors part surely many condemne opinion heart hope priuate commoditie might come vnto dissolution colledges church c doe seeme wel like wherfore teach true bucer saith nature creature note antichrist yet followeth thereof creature hath bene accidentally throughe abuse applyed idolatrie may forthwith vsed shall thinke good neither idol gentus magistrate say thing shall hencefoorth vsed thing indifferent foorthwith men vse vse haue knowledge ignorant weake take still otherwise io whitgifte answer learned famous men moment forthe answering c reason answer wordes indeede onely wordes godlinesse experience learning sake ought greater credite reason aptnesse answer referre iudgement reader seeing hath word eye note something saye vnaptly soeuer least shoulde seeme giue place plaine truth vesture neyther vsed table idolls offence weake haue wed knowne men note minister gospell aswell bell knowne rong godly prayer preaching c therefore haue spoken aunswered nothing chap diuision ansvvere admonition pag sect bullinger gualter epistle alledged answering thysbullinger gualter question whether may weare apparell papistes say sort vve shoulde haue nothing common vvith must vve forsake church refuseal liuings minister baptisme say apostle nicene creede yea quite cast avvay lordes prayer neyther borrovv ceremony matter apparell vvas neuer taken avvay beginning reformation yet reteyned pope lavv king commaundemente indifferet thing meere pollicie yea truly vveare cap peculiliar kind apparell ciuill politique thing smelleth neyther iudaisme monachisme vvill seeme separate themselues ciuill common life accompt meritorious deede vvearing peculiar garment eustathius byshop sebastia vvas notsuperstition garment condemned simply condemned vvearing peculiar kind garment put religion garment canon councell gangren laodicen sixt councell vvell knovvne case people persvvaded thing sauoure papisme monachisme iudaisme let told contrary perfectlye instructed therein importunate cry hereon people men many disquieted conscience let bevvare vvhiche bring greater yoke ovvne neck prouoke queenes maiestie bring many faithfull minister suche danger cannot ridde themselues againe hitherto bullinger c pag sect rest thing bucer bullinger gualter bring sort wherevnto answer made adde people abuse peruerte ceremony oughte better instructed counsell conuenient minister pastor whiche haue many necessarie poyntes bestowe theyr tyme enforme people shoulde bee driuen cut tyme appoynted therto teache abuse thing vse neuer well gayn nothing take heed hurte themselues thing whiche best estate doe good especially one sermon taking awaye ioyned wyth authoritie execute may doe good thousande sermon without authoritie besydes absurde ceremony whyche oughte helper promote doctrine shoulde become lettes hinderance whylest minister occupyed teachyng beware abuse superstition muche one shoulde sette watche chyide daye long least hurte himselfe knyfe takyng awaye knyfe quite daunger auoyded seruice man better employed followeth althoughe churche maye appoynte ceremony rite yet appoynte haue greate incommoditie commoditie greate offence edifying io whitgifte haue omitted diuers thing woordes learned menne wherevnto haue answered one woorde reader conference maye perceyue haue also willyngly passed ouer whiche toucheth somethyng pinchingly woordes bullinger gualter scil bee thorough importunate cry hereon people c preache truthe right vse ceremony conuenientthe reason retourned vp himselfe bycause pastor haue many necessarie poyntes c commeth passe partaker haue pestered sermon bookes therewith long tyme taught people nothyng else contempte good order obedience suche matter haue stirred vp true preacher gospell agaynst magistrate ruler selfe thyng conuenient v roote people myndes errours touchyng thing indifferent ingrafte doctrine true lawfull vse indifferent thing due obedience towardes lawes magistrate necessarie doctrine say absurde ceremony whiche oughte helper promotethe doctrine thing indifferent necessary thing abused must taken away doctrine shoulde become lettes hinderance c saye speake absurdly vndoubtedly speake vnaduisedly haue thing indifferent abrogated soone abused line east becom let hinderance whilest minister occupied teaching c take awaye tythes landes meates c abuse wherof must necessitie oftentymes reprehended sermon true vse taughte make thinges common preacher sermon maye occupied aboute greate matter doe see doctrine thinges indifferente necessarie vnderstande taking awaye thinges eye dothe roote opinion hearte thynges abused muste alwayes bee taken away abused right vse must taught abuse reproued chylde hath discretion able instructed though sometyme hurte hymselfe knyfe yet must altogether taken muste rebuked vsyng vndiscretely taughte vse better shall ryche costely apparell taken prince noble men woman estate brought popularitie therin bycause great abuse oftentymes apparell many prouocations euill truly suche kyndes abuse bee worde god reproued neyther dothe suche instruction doctrine matter indifferente hynder preacher weightyer matter didde aristotle rule nonlatin alphabet speake one thing generally euen voyde order whiche men haue commonly naturall logike reason neyther excuse selfe saying admonition giueth oftentimes occasion speake laye fault vpon beyng written diuets person matter wherof manifeste vntruth one knewe others blamed repetition one thing twice escape blame whiche myghte haue gathered easyly one place whiche sayde diuerse thing although easy booke yet wil assay doe bothe poyntes followe thinking therby bring treatise good order cast newe againe would complayne mind peruerted might remedie great disorder may boone without chaunging thyng haue set downe io whitgifte haue doone ought haue doone mente playnly haue folowed verbatim booke confute order written thinke confuteth oughte doe admonition written second reason weare apparell haue edifyed edify man would say midwiues lyed vnto pharao much good amongst israelits ergo lying much good say comparison like bycause one sinne owne nature whereas sinne take one stammereth stutteth tong edifyeth people therefore stammering stutting good edify lord giue blessing vnto word good gift hath preacheth weareth surplis c thought therefore liketh wel wearing apparell assigne cause thing cause thereof hindrance also line aking whereof supposed cause man may rather reason asmuch preach surplis c edify notwithstanding therby driuen away line cause giue suspition anabaptisme driue away othersome giue suspition euill c preached withoute wearing thinges edify much yet man assured gaine thousand may offend cause fall one brother ought io whitgifte indeede apparell nature lye similitude midwiues shew yet must necessitie confesse lying pharao much good per accidens otherwise men child israelite euen moses himselfe bin murthered ignorant diuers snow meete ye minister represent angel apparell much meete haue paire winges angel described haue put remembrance readinesse quicknesse execute office may ought weare white apparell token purenesse sinne infection glory neither haue haue ought much desire haue long worlde whereas mainteyners apparell haue theyr greatest defence thing meere ciuill let passe confounde ecclesiasticall order ciuill iustly doe confounde churche wyth common wealth saye let passe doe meanes onely make ecclesiasticall ceremonye also matter conscience line white apparell minister haue force eyther moue people minister vnto greater purenesse godlynesse whatsoeue line ought commaunded obeyed necessitie reteyned although contrarie forbidden also vertue whitegarment thereof strong worke godlynesse meete order taken play feather whitest cloth line shoulde bought often leaste euery weeke washed good la line nder sope white vnderstand topicall place ho line deth line hings ly quae aliquid line ac unt helpe white helpeth whych white helpeth moste godlynesse although line churche haue authoritie make ceremonyes accordyng rule recited god glory profiting congregation coulde neuer yet learne power gyue newe signification institute newe sacramentes thys meanes taken cleane away v holde whiche haue agaynst papistes whereby agaynst goodly shewes make colour signification saye worde god sacramentes baptisme supper lorde sufficient teache admoni line put v remembraunce duetie whatsoeuer nowe come superstition grecian wyll haue neyther grauen car line ed image theyr church paynted neyther haue grauen carued paynted wouen truely see cause w line may haue wel holy water holy bread thys reason heere good sure signification glorious surplice call remembrance necessarie thing sayde maye leaste number ceremonyes shoulde greate maye easily answered whiche haue maye taken awaye set place therefore althoughe surplice haue blacke spotte whitest yet blacke make wyth white signification cause cu line line fende presse wyth martyr bucers authoritie easie kind answering first say men line therefore although otherwyse watchfull yet slept time appeale apocrypha vnto knowne writing theyr priuate letter vnto theyr publike recordes io whitgifte haue onely set downe martyr word shew might iustly bring fit profitable signification apparell author admonition doe sitting communion dyd allow signification sitting neyther doe approue suche signification apparell yet gyue leaue set one agaynste shewe mighte aswell doe one doe peruert master martyr wordes sayth muche angel appearedmeere ciuill thing may haue signification white apparell minister churche angel god messenger therefore churche maye appoynt hir minister suche apparell signification office doe answere range vp downe pleasure like vnto spaniell taughte followe game martyr doth say apparell signe purenesse minister therefore youthe forme apparell may put man minde dutie write confuting myght haue bene cutte well spared master martyr shoulde haue sayde maye signe purenesse oughte minister seeke answere yet christ beyng puritie selfe needed nothyng put hym mynde thereof man beyng impure may haue externall instrumentes byd hym remember ought thinke seuerall kyndes habites appoynted men diuerse degree calling partly purpose man graue apparell vse hymselfe lightly wantonly vse commonly saye suche behauiour becommeth apparell meanyng hys habite apparell oughte put mynde modestie grauitie thys doth argue euen meere ciuill thing maye haue signification whiche ouerthroweth argument whereby woulde proue apparell muste necessitie ecclesiasticall ceremonie bycause attributed vnto signification whether matter meare ciuill meare ecclesiasticall mixt questio neither yet whether church may confounded wyth common wealth therfore deale anye leaste shoulde confounde matter reader onely speake argument whiche confuted common vsage seuerall habites vniuersities signifie seuerall degree learnyng seuerall kynde apparell seuerall calling function common wealthe thys apparell doth put euerie man mynde hys duetie yet longer reteined magistrate lawes doe permitte alterable accordyng tymes place person man sayth vertue garmentes power worke godlynesse therefore pretie iestes builded vpon ground vayne toyish topicall place rightly vnderstanded ment thing quae per se aliquid faciunt euery thing signifieth thing sacrament matrimonie asacrament laying hand like papistes vsed vnlawfull signes attributed vnto life death made necessarie saluation image whether grauen paynted wouen agaynste expresse commaundement god therefore vnapte similitude neyther woulde haue vsed well considered martyr wordes answere allegation holy water holy bread pseudoadiaphora haue annexed vnto opinion saluation worship vtterly remoue order answere martyr bucers authoritie sure greatly commendablet c refuseth ye iudgement learned men whe cannot otherwise anwere men wri ting circumstance time place must distin guished easiest worst answere denie authoritie wise learned famous men without reason onely cauilling knowne writing written purpose vpon controuersies according circumstance time place person therefore thing publike writing seeme iudgements distinguishe tyme circumstance doubt well agree themselues interim doe endeuour deface chap ninth diuision admonition haue shewe euill seing popishe priesthood euill ansvvere knoweth apparell nowe signes massing priest lawfull minister wherfore shew good euen like manner vniuersities shewe signe degree learning therefore shewe good excepte also condemne degree learning neither straunge matter selfe thing diuerse respect diuerse time signe good euill bel signe euill whe rung cal masse stay stormes tempest selfe bel signe good rung sermon godly action church themselues signe euil whe idolatrie committed false doctrine preached signe good god rightly worshipped worde truely preached many example could bring reasonable gather sufficiently confute error futhermore willed absteyne shewe euill ment euill life euil doctrine least doe thing scrupulous conscience c pag tovvardes ende doctor proceedeth proue signes shewes good euil ye author admonition tymes paste common bishop nowe proper bishop rome therefore hated sake whome nowe signifieth tyrannus sometyme signified king generally line e signinifyetha lawfull name maye remaine though hath bene abused cruell king bloudie gouernoure therefore also abhorred archbishop though person sometime haue degenerated yet name hath continued signification therfore reasen nothing lyke except wil also lyke cause codemne name bishop king haue bene many euill men called name bishop many tyrant name king yet name neuer worsse name shoulde chaunged ofte abused nede haue office inuent new name certaine kinde heretikes called themselues apostolike yet name apostle neuer worse lawfull name lawfull office may remaine together office howesoeuer tyme hath bin abused chap diuision c pag sect nowe name ought odious horribly abused also petitio principii haue yet proued forbidden sauior christ thing themselues must greater hatred vnlawfulnesse whereof may thus appeare io whitgifte manifest petition principle pointe yet proued let v heare reason office condemned chap diuision c pag sect first ministerie word god heauenly left wil men toscriptures willingly falsified make serue turne deuise thou neither christ elia ye prophet baptizest thou whych ben good argument iohn might haue ben function tha ordinarie churche instituted god therfore iohn establish singular extraordinarie function alledgeth worde god whereby appeareth lawfull bring strange doctrine lawfull teach true doctrine vnder name function instituted god io whitgifte fyrst argument phariseys comming iohn baptist denyed eyther christ elia prophet conclude thou neyther chryste elia prophet baptizest thou ergo may archbishop meaning least shoulde thinke cauill vse owne conclusion ergo ordinarie function churche argument hath neyther head foote forme matter exquisitenessethe disordered argument ye replier logike first antecedent vntrue builded vpon false allegation scripture phariseys doe say vnto thou bee neyther christ elia prophet wordes text thou bee christ elia prophet great difference betwixt two kynde speaches thou prophet thou prophet first signifieth aske whether prophet whether prophet looked suche one moyses according written deut vers else iohn wolddeut haue denied haue bin prophet seeing christ sayth one math moreouer aske ordinarie function inmath church extraordinarie person looked executed earthly men minister also chosen men like vnto themselues yet bicause done worde institution god hath ordeyned worde preached hath ordeined also order whome preached may well accompted come
